newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia refiners warn of plant closures.
newsitem.headline: Australia refiners warn of plant closures.

text.p: Australia's refining industry on Thursday warned it was seriously considering closing down plants unless profitability was restored to sustainable levels.
The Australian Institute of Petroleum, which represents the four locally-based refiners, issued the warning after it released an independent report outlining the slump in profits.

"Some of the Australian refineries may have to close and that's a possibility that's been flagged by one or two of the four refining companies," institute executive director Jim Starkey told reporters on Thursday.
Australia's eight refineries are run by the Royal Dutch/Shell group, Mobil Corp, British Petroleum Plc and Ampol, a joint venture between Caltex Australia Ltd and Pioneer International Ltd.
Ampol, Australia's largest refiner and marketer, and Shell have both canvassed the possibility of plant closures.
"This is the first time I have heard the refiners talking about the possibility of refinery closures and they are at a point where it's being considered as a serious possibility," Starkey added.
The annual report, prepared by accountants Ernst and Young, showed that underlying refinery earnings for calendar 1996 in Australia represented a return of just 5.2 percent on equity.
Net sales revenue for the four refiners rose 10 percent in 1996, but on a per-unit basis net sales revenue has fallen 12 percent in real terms for all products since 1992, it said.
Net profit, adjusted for a revaluation of stocks, amounted to a total A$222 million, it lowest level since the annual survey of refiners' profits began in 1992.
"We are now looking at a really low level of new investment now being put into the industry...," said the institute's manager of government and public policy, Ewan Macpherson.
Capital expenditure totalled A$623 million in 1996.
"There's been a major reduction year on year," he said.
The institute said refiners needed a freer hand to restructure its retail network of service stations in order to improve profitability to sustainable levels.
The institute said current laws inhibits the extent to which retailers can control the retail market by limiting the number of service stations they can operate to five percent.
Refiners want this restriction loosened.
Australia has about 9,000 service stations.
The number is shrinking as competition, a glut of cheap imported petrol and a squeeze on profit margins from refineries to the petrol pump reshapes the industry, the institute said.
The local refiners own about 3,400 local service stations but claim current laws limit their ability to respond to new, independently owned stations mushrooming around the country.
The independents, including surpermarket chain Woolworths Ltd, are selling a lot of Asian product into Australia.
In response, refiners want to close many of their smaller service stations, merge them or build new ones able to compete with the large, independent outlets.
"The need is urgent because the companies are bleeding," Starkey said.
-- Melbourne bureau 613-92861421
